200.description: Everything worked as expected.

202.description: The request has been accepted for processing.

204.description: An API request was successful, but there is no response body to return.

400.description: There was a parsing or validation error in the request. Bad Request errors typically include `path` and `location` in the response to help you find the cause of the error.

401.description: Authentication information (the app key and secret or bearer token) was either incorrect or missing.

403.description: Authentication was correct, but the user does not have permission to access the requested API, e.g., if the feature in question is not included in your pricing plan.

405.description: Returned when a request is made using an HTTP method not supported by the endpoint. For example, sending a DELETE to /api/schedules.

406.description: Return when the client requests a version of the API that cannot be satisfied, because no compatible version is currently deployed.

409.description: The request conflicts with another request.

413.description: Returned when the request is too large to be processed.

429.description: Too many requests hit the API too quickly. For example, if we are not ready to create a channel for this payload; e.g., it is rate limited. You should wait before retrying the channel creation.

absoluteWindow.description: An object with `start` and `end` attributes containing ISO-formatted dates specifying an absolute window of time.
absoluteWindow.title: Absolute window of time

actionsObject.description: Describes Actions to be performed by the SDK when a user interacts with the notification. You can personalize message actions using [Handlebars](https://docs.airship.com/guides/messaging/personalization/handlebars/).

add_custom_event.description: Emit a custom event when a user interacts with the push notification.

name.description: The name of the custom event.

properties.description: A JSON object with the properties associated with the event.

value.description: An integer or decimal value of the event.

app_defined.description: A map of registered action names to payloads as defined by the app or SDK. Some of these actions are supported as their own property on the Actions object, but be aware that their registered names in the SDK may be different. For a summary of the actions registered by the SDK, including usage information, see the [Mobile](https://docs.airship.com/developer/sdk-integration/mobile/actions/) docs.

open.description: Open action. When a user interacts with the notification, opens one of: URL, deep link, or landing page as described in the associated `content` property.

oneOf.description: Opens a URL or passes a string for use as a custom action.

content.description: Any string. A URL string that starts with either `http` or `https` will open a URL or a string that starts with `tel:` followed by a sequence of numbers will open the phone app.

oneOf.title: Open URL Action

fallback_url.description: A URL that can be used on platforms that don't have full support for the otherwise defined action.
fallback_url.title: Fallback URL

share.description: String indicating the text that will populate the share action.

subscription_list.description: Alter subscription list membership for a channel or contact.

oneOf.description: Alters Subscription List membership for a channel.
oneOf.title: Channel Subscription List action

oneOf.description: Alters subscription list membership for a contact.
oneOf.title: Contact subscription list action

actionsObject.title: Actions

activityObject.description:
The `activity` object defines the target audience based on lifecycle actions or Custom Event activity, using comparison operators on activity count and recency. Optionally include a `where` object, which filters for specific activity values.

In the example to the right, the target audience is users who have opened your app from a notification from the "neowise" campaign at least twice, 3 days ago.

activity.description:
The target event activity, e.g., `app_open`.

Default event values are enumerated below. If you create a custom or predefined event that you wish to segment users on, you must register the event in the Airship dashboard. See [Manage events](https://docs.airship.com/guides/messaging/project/config/events/).

after.description: A date value for an absolute comparison or an integer value for a relative comparison.

before.description: A date value for an absolute comparison or an integer value for a relative comparison.

metric.description:
The metric you are targeting for the event.

When using the metric `count` or `total_value`, `operator` and `value` are required.

When using either `first` or `last`, `operator` and `value` are not allowed. Use one of the following combinations instead:

* `before`/`precision`
* `after`/`precision`
* `on`/`on_precision`

| Metric | Description |
|---|---|
| `count` | Evaluate based on the number of event occurrences. |
| `total_value`   | Evaluate based on the cumulative event `value` associated with the target user. |
| `last` | Evaluate based on the last occurrence of an event for a given user/time window. |
| `first` | Evaluate based on the first occurrence of an event for a given user/time window. |

on.description:
Use `on` in conjunction with the `first` or `last` metric to indicate either a specific date or period with precision. Use either:

* A date in ISO 8601 format, e.g., `2020-08-10T17:28:34+0000` or
* An integer that, when combined with the `on_precision` property, specifies the time period. For example, use `"on": 12` with `"on_precision: "month"` to target events that occurred in December.

on_precision.description: When using the `first` or `last` metric with the `on` property to target events on. For example, for the 5th of any month, or only in March, use `on_precision`.

operator.description: The comparison operator used to evaluate the activity expression. Use these operators (greater/less than, equal to, equal or greater/equal or less) when the `metric` is either `count` or `total_value`.

precision.description:
If using a relative number (integer) for the `before`/`after`/`on` property,
the `precision` value will be interpreted as the number of time units ago, e.g.,
*7 days ago*. Defaults to `days`.

value.description: The value that the `operator` uses to evaluate the target audience.

activityObject.title: Activity audience object

notification_tag.description: A string representing a notification tag. If a message is currently displaying and has a tag set, sending another message with the same tag will replace the posted notification.

This object must contain a string field `type` which must be one of `big_picture`, `big_text`, or `inbox`. It may also contain `title` and `summary` override fields.

big_picture.description: If the `type` is set to `big_picture`, then there must also be a `big_picture` string field which contains the URL for an image.

big_text.description: If the `type` is set to `big_text`, then a `big_text` string field must be present with the text to be shown in big text style.

lines.description: An array of strings if the `type` field is set to `inbox`.

items.description: If the `type` field is set to `inbox` then a `lines` field should be provided as an array of strings.

summary.description: A string field which will override the summary of the notification.

title.description: A string field which will override the title of the notification.

androidOverrideObject.description: The platform override section for Android. Maximum 4,096 bytes.

alert.description: A string that override the alert value provided at the top level, if any.

category.description: Helps determine notification sort order. Available on Android Lollipop+.

collapse_key.description: A key indicating that this message can replace, or be replaced by, another message with the same `collapse_key`. This feature comes into play when a device is offline (e.g., airplane mode) or in doze mode; if multiple messages are available with the same collapse_key when a device comes back online, it will display only the most recent message and discard previous messages using the same `collapse_key`.

delay_while_idle.description: After November 15, 2016, this was still accepted by GCM, but ignored. When set to `true`, it indicates that the message should not be sent until the device becomes active. The default value is false.

deliver_to.description: Filters out Android channels that are not able to receive notifications. If the value is `opted_in`, the payload is only sent to opted-in devices. If the value is `all`, the payload is sent to opted-in and background enabled devices. Defaults to `all` if not provided.

delivery_priority.description: Sets the FCM/GCM priority of the message. Defaults to `normal` if not provided.

extra.description: A JSON dictionary of string-to-string key-value pairs. The keys `from`, `message_type`, `data` and keys that start with `google` or `gcm` are disallowed.

icon.description: A string representing an image file included in the application’s resources.

icon_color.description: A string representing the icon color in API Color Format. i.e., `#rrggbb`

live_update.description:
JSON object that represents the content sent to a Live Update notification. Live Updates are an [AXP feature](https://docs.airship.com/reference/feature-packages/). 

**Note**: Using this object transforms the Android notification to a Live Update notification.
When `event` is equal to `start`, the entire targeted audience will receive the Live Update content.
When `event` is equal to `update` or `end`, only devices that have a Live Update started for the specified `name` field will receive the Live Update content.

content_state.description: A dictionary of string keys to arbitrary JSON values that represents the content state to be updated by the Live Activity or Live Update notification.
content_state.title: Content state

dismissal_date.description: An optional epoch timestamp in seconds, used when you end the Live Update.

event.description:
Use `start` to start a Live Update.
Use `update` to update a current Live Update.
Use `end` to emit the last update and end the Live Update.

name.description: The name of the Live Update to target. When `event` is equal to `update` or `end`, the audience will be limited to devices that have a Live Update started for the specified name.

timestamp.description: An optional epoch timestamp in seconds, used to enforce the Live Update ordering. If you don't provide one, the current timestamp is used.

type.description: Used to map Live Update events to the corresponding handler in your app.

local_only.description: If true, the notification is only shown on wearable devices.

notification_channel.description: A string representing a notification channel. Used to group notifications with similar behavior.

notification_tag.description: A string representing a notification tag. If a message is currently displaying and has a tag set, sending another message with the same tag will replace the posted notification. Similar to the iOS `collapse_id`.

priority.description: An integer in the range from -2 to 2 inclusive. Used to help determine notification sort order. 2 is the highest priority, -2 is the lowest, and 0 is the default priority.

public_notification.description: An optional notification to show on lock screen instead of the redacted one. This is only useful with visibility set to -1 (private). The object may contain any of the following string fields `title`, `alert`, and `summary`.

sound.description: A string representing a sound file name included in the application’s resources.

style.description: Advanced styles `big text`, `big picture`, and `inbox` are available on Android 4.3+ by adding the `style` to the platform specific notification payload on Android platforms. This object must contain a string field `type` which must be one of `big_picture`, `big_text`, or `inbox`. It may also contain `title` and `summary` override fields.

big_picture.description: If the `type` is set to `big_picture`, then there must also be a `big_picture` string field which contains the URL for an image.

big_text.description: If the `type` is set to `big_text`, then a `big_text` string field must be present with the text to be shown in big text style.

lines.description: An array of strings if the `type` field is set to `inbox`.

items.description: If the `type` field is set to `inbox` then a `lines` field should be provided as an array of strings.

summary.description: A string field which will override the summary of the notification.

title.description: A string field which will override the title of the notification.

kid.description: The key used to sign the JWT, the `client_id`.

exp.description: The `assertion`'s expiration timestamp in seconds since epoch, after which it is not valid. The expiry must not be more than 10 minutes in the future. This is for the `assertion`, not for the token that will be returned. Example: `1681862754`

iat.description: The issue timestamp in seconds since epoch. Example: `168186250`

ipaddr.description: A space-delimited list of CIDR representations of valid IP addresses to which the issued token is restricted.

nonce.description: A unique string that must not have been used recently with this `client_id`. We will store this for a minimum of 2 hours. If you are relying on the nonce to defend against replay attacks, it is recommended to also enforce a narrow *ipaddr* range in order to prevent requests that utilize the returned access token from being replayed by an outside client.

scope.description: A space-delimited list of scopes to which the returned claim should be restricted. If not provided, the full list of scopes the `client_id` is granted will be in the returned claim.

sub.description: A space-delimited set of identifiers for which subjects a token is allowed. An `app` subject is required. Example: `app:JQIMcndxIHWy2QISpt1SpZ`.

assertionJwt.description: A JSON Web Token (JWT) used for authorization in [OAuth token requests](#operation-token-post). The JWT must be signed with the private key corresponding to the `client_id` in the `kid` header using the ES384 algorithm.
assertionJwt.title: Assertion JWT

atomicSelector.description: Atomic selectors are the simplest way to identify a single device, i.e., app or browser installation, or a group of devices. These selectors are either a unique identifier for the device such as a Channel ID or metadata that maps to the device (or multiple devices) such as a tag.

oneOf.description: The simplest selector, which targets the entire audience.
oneOf.title: All selector

oneOf.description: A tag is an arbitrary bit of metadata used for targeting devices. A tag specifier may or may not have an associated group declaration, indicating a `tag group` the tag belongs to, for example,  `{"tag": "silver-member", "group": "loyalty"}`. If no tag group is specified, the default `device` group is used.
oneOf.title: Tag selector

oneOf.description: The unique channel identifier used to target an open channel device or web device, i.e., web browser.
oneOf.title: Channel selector

oneOf.description: A `named_user` is an alternate, non-unique name, mapped to a user profile in a different database, e.g., CRM, that can be used to target devices associated with that profile.
oneOf.title: Named User selector

oneOf.description: The unique channel identifier used to target a Fire OS device.
oneOf.title: Fire OS channel selector

oneOf.description: The unique channel identifier used to target an Android device.
oneOf.title: Android channel selector

oneOf.description: The unique channel identifier used to target a device on an open platform.
oneOf.title: Open channel selector

oneOf.description: A long or short code the app is configured to send from. For example, `12345`.
oneOf.title: SMS sender selector

oneOf.description: Selects a single SMS device. The `msisdn` must be `opted_in` to receive notifications.

sender.description: The sender that the app is configured to send SMS messages from.

oneOf.title: SMS ID selector

oneOf.description: A `static_list` is a subset of your audience defined by a CSV file containing Channel IDs or Named Users.
oneOf.title: Static list selector

oneOf.description: An single instance or array of [subscription list IDs](#schemas-subscriptionlistobject-list_id).
oneOf.title: Subscription List selector

oneOf.description: A legacy mechanism used for mapping devices to a customer ID, e.g., a CRM identifier. Superseded by `named_user`.
oneOf.title: Alias selector

oneOf.description: A legacy identifier for targeting Android and Windows devices, superseded by `android_channel`.
oneOf.title: APID selector

oneOf.description: A special selector used in Pipelines to indicate that the audience of the push is composed of the device or devices that activated the trigger. See [Pipeline objects](#schema-tag-pipeline-objects) for more information.
oneOf.title: Triggered selector

atomicSelector.title: Atomic selector

attributes.description:
Attributes associated with a channel or Named User. This object contains predefined attributes that you enable and assign to the channel, or custom attributes that you create and assign.

This object enumerates predefined attributes, but you can [create your own in the Airship dashboard](https://docs.airship.com/guides/messaging/audience/segmentation/attributes/adding/).

account_creation.description: The [date-time](#date-time-format) when the user created their account.

advertising_id.description: The IDFA associated with a user.

altitude.description: The altitude associated with a user.

city.description: The city associated with the user.

company.description: The company that a user is associated with.

country.description: The country associated with the user.

first_name.description: The first name of a user.

full_name.description: A user's first and last names.

home_phone.description: The user's home phone number — similar to an SMS channel `msisdn`.

last_name.description: The last name of a user.

latitude.description: The latitude associated with a user — maybe their default location.

longitude.description: The longitude associated with a user — maybe their default location.

loyalty_tier.description: The loyalty program tier that a user is associated with, e.g., gold, platinum, etc.

mobile_phone.description: The user's mobile phone number — similar to an SMS channel `msisdn`.

region.description: The state, province, principality, etc. associated with the user.

title.description: A default attribute. You must enable this attribute in the dashboard before you can assign it.

username.description: A user's username — generally a part of their login information.

work_phone.description: The user's work phone number — similar to an SMS channel `msisdn`.

zipcode.description: A user's zipcode. This is different from the SMS channel `ua_ndc` attribute, that records user's area code or phone number prefix.

attributes.title: Custom and predefined Attributes

attributesArray.description: The array can hold string, number, boolean, objects, and array.  Accepts numbers and strings for integer/number type attributes, but your string must be convertible to a number or the request will fail. Objects must be valid JSON or the request will fail.
attributesArray.title: Array

attributes.description: The attributes that you want to set for, or remove from, your `audience`. You can have both `set` and `remove` actions in the same request.

audienceLimitsObject.description: Defines limits to be applied to Push Notifications and standard in-app messages (not In-App Automations or Scenes) only. See [Audience Limit](https://docs.airship.com/guides/messaging/messages/delivery/#audience-limit) in the *Message delivery* user guide for additional information and limitations.

max_recipients.description: The maximum number of recipients a push can be delivered to.

audienceLimitsObject.title: Audience limits object

audienceSelector100.description: An audience selector forms the expression that determines the set of channels to target.
audienceSelector100.title: Audience selector (max 100)

audienceSelector1000.description: An audience selector forms the expression that determines the set of channels to target.
audienceSelector1000.title: Audience selector (max 1000)

banListParametersObject.description: A list of parameters, where the key and value are both strings, that will be used to override the default values set for variables in a [Ban List](https://docs.airship.com/guides/messaging/project/config/ban-lists/) request URL.
banListParametersObject.title: Ban List parameters

bulkSendObject.description: A bulk send object describes everything about a [Send message with bulk ID](#operation-api-bulk-send-post) or [Schedule message with bulk ID](#operation-api-schedules-bulk-send-post) notification. The acceptable fields are identical to a standard push with two exceptions. The audience field can only be a single `bulk_id` and there can only be one `device_type`.

bulk_id.description: A unique string obtained from the [Create bulk send audience operation](#operation-api-bulk-platform_name-post) to target an audience for bulk sending.

device_types.description: An array containing exactly one targeted platform.

global_attributes.description: The global attributes object may contain an arbitrary set of keys and values, including arrays and nested objects, which will be added to the global attributes rendering namespace for this push. Top-level keys must start with a letter and cannot start with the reserved sequence ``ua_``. If the global attributes object is nonempty, it implies the ``personalization: true`` option.
global_attributes.title: Global attributes

localizations.description: An array of localizations. Channels bearing the specified language/country combination will receive the corresponding message.

orchestration.description:
An object used to indicate the strategy to employ when deciding which channels to target for a contact.
An orchestration object can be stored in Airship as the default strategy. If the orchestration section is included in a push payload,
it will override the configured default value. The overall default strategy is `fan_out`.

channel_priority.description: An array of channel types in priority order. Required if `type` is set to `channel_priority`.

items.description: A channel type. One of `app`, `web`, `sms`, `email`, and `open::<open_platform_name>`

type.description: The name of the orchestration strategy to employ.

orchestration.title: Orchestration object

bulkSendObject.title: Bulk send object

campaignsObject.description: An object specifying custom campaign categories related to the notification.

categories.description: Array of strings representing the campaigns you wish to associate with the notification. Must have between 1 to 10 items in the array with a 64 character/byte maximum per item.

campaignsObject.title: Campaigns object

channelContactOperationDeviceInfoObject.description: Additional device information that is not included in the headers.

device_type.description: The device type of the channel.

channelContactOperationDeviceInfoObject.title: Channel Contact operation device info object

channelContactOperationIdentifyActionObj.description: A Channel Contact operation using this object associates a channel to a Named User and attempts to identify the Named User with a specific Contact ID. If the Named User does not yet exist, it will be created with the [Anonymous Contact](https://docs.airship.com/developer/sdk-integration/mobile/audience/#contacts) ID that the channel is already associated to. If the channel is not associated to an Anonymous Contact, the Named User will be created using the optionally provided Contact ID or a randomly generated Contact ID if there is no Contact ID provided or the provided Contact ID is already bound to a Named User.

contact_id.description: Contact ID to associate to the Named User if it is not already associated to a Contact. Otherwise it will be ignored.

named_user_id.description: Identifies the Named User, with no leading or trailing whitespace.

type.description: The action to be carried out.

channelContactOperationIdentifyActionObj.title: Identify action object

channelContactOperationResetActionObject.description: A Channel Contact operation using this object is mostly equivalent to [Named Users disassociation](#operation-api-named_users-disassociate-post), but instead of leaving the channel disassociated, it associates the channel to a new [Anonymous Contact](https://docs.airship.com/developer/sdk-integration/mobile/audience/#contacts) after disassociation from the current Contact.

type.description: The action to be carried out.

channelContactOperationResetActionObject.title: Reset action object

channelContactOperationResolveActionObje.description: A Channel Contact operation using this object results in either resolving the current associated Contact (named or anonymous) for that channel or it will associate that channel to an [Anonymous Contact](https://docs.airship.com/developer/sdk-integration/mobile/audience/#contacts), always returning a Contact ID for the SDK to store. A Contact ID can optionally be provided, which the channel will be associated to in the event the channel is not already associated to a Contact and the provided Contact ID is not already bound to a Named User.

contact_id.description: Contact ID to associate to the channel if it is not already associated to a Contact.

type.description: The action to be carried out.

channelContactOperationResolveActionObje.title: Resolve action object

channel_association_timestamp.description: The [date-time](#date-time-format) when the channel association occurred.

is_anonymous.description: Specifies whether the Contact is anonymous or not.

address.description: The address to send push notifications to when `device_type` is `email` or `open`. For all other `device_type` values, this key is replaced with `push_address`.

alias.description: Displays the alias associated with the channel, if one exists. Aliases are the precursor to Named Users, our user mapping system. If you are using aliases, please upgrade to Named Users. Listed as `null` when not set.

attributes.description:
A dictionary of attributes that you've associated with the channel. See the [Attributes guide](https://docs.airship.com/guides/messaging/audience/segmentation/attributes/) for more information about creating and assigning attributes.

The attributes listed here are "predefined" by Airship, but you can create new attributes in the Airship dashboard.

background.description: If true, the device can receive background push notifications. If false, it cannot. This field only appears for iOS devices.

channel_id.description: The unique channel identifier for a device.

commercial_opted_in.description:
The [date-time](#date-time-format) when a user gave explicit permission to receive commercial
emails.

commercial_opted_out.description:
The [date-time](#date-time-format) when a user explicitly denied permission to receive
commercial emails.

device_type.description: Specifies the device platform for a channel.

email_address.description: The email address associated with the email channel when `device_type` is `email`.

installed.description: If true, the channel is installed. If false, it is uninstalled.

last_registration.description: The last registration [date-time](#date-time-format) of this channel, if known.

msisdn.description: The phone number associated with the SMS channel. Must be numeric characters only, without leading zeros.

named_user_id.description: A customer-chosen ID that represents the device user, e.g., CRM ID. This ID cannot have leading or trailing whitespace. Listed as `null` when not set.

opt_in.description: If true, the channel is opted in to push notifications. If false, it is not. Required for all types except email.

opt_in_date.description: `(SMS only)` The [date-time](#date-time-format) when the SMS channel gave permission to receive messages.

opt_out_date.description: `(SMS only)` The [date-time](#date-time-format) when the SMS channel opted out of receiving messages.

push_address.description: Required if `opt_in` is true. The address to send push notifications to for all `device_type` values other than `email` and `open`. When `device_type` is `email` or `open`, this key is replaced with `address`.

subscription_lists.description: Lists all the subscription lists that this channel is subscribed to.

suppression_state.description:
If an email channel is suppressed, the reason for its suppression. Email
channels with any suppression state set will not have any delivery to
them fulfilled. If a more specific reason is not known, use `imported`.

tag_groups.description: One or more tag group objects (including [Device Property Tags](https://docs.airship.com/reference/device-property-tags/)) associated with this channel.

tags.description: An array of tags associated with this channel.

transactional_opted_in.description:
The [date-time](#date-time-format) when a user gave explicit permission to receive transactional
emails. Users do not need to opt-in to receive transactional
emails unless they have previously opted out.

transactional_opted_out.description:
The [date-time](#date-time-format) when a user explicitly denied permission to receive
transactional emails.

web.description: Contains parameters that apply when the `device_type` is set to `web`.

subscription.description: The web subscription. This optional field is not present for cases where a browser is registered (for purposes of Feature Flags) but isn't opted-in to push notifications.

keys.description: Encryption keys required for signing the push package.

web.title: Web channel properties

complexEventSelector.description:
An event selector is a JSON dictionary consisting of a set of (possibly negated)
event-specific selectors joined together by a doubly-nested set of operators,
in disjunctive or conjunctive normal form. That is, only queries of the pattern
"single AND of ORs" or "single OR of ANDs" are allowed (no further nesting is allowed),
and only leaf nodes of such queries may be negated. Elision of single-value operators
is allowed for the sake of brevity/usability on writes, but responses from our servers
will always be fully qualified.

Event-specific selectors are allowed to reference any field in a potentially matching
event, at any nesting depth therein, with the goal of matching their structure to
existing API formats, both inbound and outbound.

Top-level operator dictionaries are of the form `{"and": []}` or `{"or": []}`, where the members
of the array will be operator dictionaries of the other type ("AND of ORs" or "OR of ANDs"),
or if eliding on ingress, negation operator dictionaries or event-specific selectors.

Negation operator dictionaries are of the form `{"not": {}}` where the inner object is strictly
an event-specific selector. I.e., only leaf nodes may be negated, in keeping with the tenets of
conjunctive/disjunctive normal form.

oneOf.description: Defines an event value to match.

key.description: The field you want to match a value against.

scope.description: Specifies an inner-dictionary on a potentially-matching event.

value.description:
Specifies the criteria qualifying a value as a match. Integer values support
up to 6 digits of decimal precision. You can specify a range of values using
`at_least`/`greater_than` and `at_most`/`less_than`, but the value for
`at_least`/`greater_than` must be less than the value of `at_most`/`less_than`
or your request will return an error.

array_contains.description: Matches if an array contains the specified string value.

at_least.description: Matches values greater than the specified value.

at_most.description: Matches values less than the specified value.

equals.description: Specifies an exact match. String values are case sensitive and must match exactly.

greater_than.description: Matches values greater than the specified value.

less_than.description: Matches values less than the specified value.

oneOf.title: Event value selector

not.description: Defines an event value to match.

key.description: The field you want to match a value against.

scope.description: Specifies an inner-dictionary on a potentially-matching event.

value.description:
Specifies the criteria qualifying a value as a match. Integer values support
up to 6 digits of decimal precision. You can specify a range of values using

`at_least`/`greater_than` must be less than the value of `at_most`/`less_than`
